subject: Re: testing distributed components
msgSnippet: ... of your ... tricky ... component. ... create test ... method of ... to be ... some ... interface ... actual work. ... BarImpl and ... object to ... Hi,
messageBody:
--- In junit@egroups.com, Kevin Bourrillion <kevinb@m...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> As the name "unit testing" suggests, your best bet is to test each
of your
> components one by one, in isolation. But as you say, that can be
tricky
> when the input to your component needs to come from some other
component.
> In these cases you may find it worthwhile to invest the time to
create test
> stubs for these objects.
>
> Here's an elementary example: Suppose you're testing the "foo"
method of
> your "Comp" component. However, this method requires a "Bar" object
to be
> passed in, and the only way to get one of these is to interact with
some
> other component(s)--something of a unit-testing "no-no."
>
> public interface Comp {
> public void foo(Bar bar);
> }
>
> What you want to do is create another implementation of the Bar
interface
> called TestBar, which returns dummy test data instead of doing
actual work.
> (If Bar is not already an interface, renaming it something like
BarImpl and
> making Bar an interface!) Then create an instance of this TestBar
object to
> test your foo() method with.
>
> Does this help, or is it too elementary?

Hi,

Thanks for this, I have a similar problem...

My problem is not so much component dependencies (I guess everyone has
those), but proliferation of data which it's very hard to create
dummy versions of. This is because the data depends on other data,
and is typically meaningless without it.

To give a concrete description, we work with airline resource
optimization. Suppose I want to test the flight connections module. I
can't do this without creating some connection data. Connection data
is meaningless without flight data. Flight data is meaningless without
aircraft and airport data. Then you need aircraft type, and
location descriptions, and so on.

Also, the nature of optimization is such that, generally, testing
anything using 2 airports and one flight is not going to tell you
anything meaningful about whether anything works or not. Thus creating
manageable amounts of dummy data is problematic in itself.

Of course, I can use real data, and all the necessary components to
load and manipulate it. But then I'm barely unit-testing, am I?
It basically turns into functional testing in any case.

Does anyone have any insights/experience of similar problems?

Geoff Bache
